occurrences.line_text: Or anguish in her hart, is hard to tell:
And raise againe to life the hart, that she did thrill.
Which sinfull horror workes in wounded hart,
And sharpe Remorse his hart did pricke and nip,
Hart cannot thinke, what outrage, and what cryes,
Possessed of his Ladies hart and hand,
His onely hart sore, and his onely foe,
As if her hart with sorrow had transfixed beene.
Which she increased with her bleeding hart,
His hart gan wexe as starke, as marble stone,
And goodly counsell, that for wounded hart
Haue not all seized on your frozen hart,
From teares abstaine, for griefe his hart did grate,
And with bold furie armes the weakest hart;
Now gan his hart all swell in iollitie,
My feeble courage, and my hart oppresse,
The knight emboyling in his haughtie hart,
With hart then throbbing, and with watry eyes,
My hart, my hands, mine eyes, and all assayd?
That welnigh molt his hart in raging yre,
Direfull impatience, and hart murdring loue;
Ne let thy stout hart melt in pitty vayne:
So did she all, that might his constant hart
And euer held his hand vpon his hart:
In slouthfull sleepe his molten hart to steme,
Of courteous clemencie in gentle hart.
Though somewhat moued in his mightie hart,
That his deepe wounded hart in two did riue,
That hart of flint a sunder could haue rift:
Gaue him great hart, and hope of victory.
And his deare hart the picture gan adore,
Ran to his hart, and all his sence dismayd,
His hart in twaine with sad melancholy,
His hart with great affection was embayd,
That in the secret of your hart close lyes,
Ne was there outward breach, nor grudge in hart,
That quite his hart from Guendolene remou'd,
When the hart bloud should gush out of his chest,
And trembling terror did his hart apall,
So riu'd her trembling hart, and wicked end did make.
Your stubborne hart t'affect with fraile infirmity.
Faire Daphne Phoebus hart with loue did gore;
And all, that might his melting hart entise
Need but behold the pourtraict of her hart,
When first her tender hart was with his beautie smit.
So did she steale his heedelesse hart away,
Her fickle hart conceiued hasty fire,
And in each gentle hart desire of honour breeds.
Of her false eyes, that at her hart did ayme,
Wherewith imperious loue her hart did vexe,
Her hart on knight so goodly glorifide,
And softly sunck into her molten hart;
Hart that is inly hurt, is greatly eased
And thinke of that faire visage, written in her hart.
To let the secret of her hart to her appeare.
Another arrow hath your louers hart to hit.
And suckes the bloud, which from my hart doth bleed.
Nor so did Biblis spend her pining hart,
Her loue-sicke hart to other thoughts did steale;
Out of her daughters hart fond fancies to reuerse.
And with sharpe fits thy tender hart oppresseth sore.
Friendship professed with vnfained hart,
And the deepe wound more deepe engord her hart,
But well I wote, that to an heauy hart
Panting for breath, and almost out of hart,
And haply in her hart find highest rowme,
The point of pitty perced through her tender hart.
But hurt his hart, the which before was sound,
So still his hart woxe sore, and health decayd:
That neither bloud in face, nor life in hart
Yet neuer he his hart to her reuealed,
A loue-sick hart, she did to him enuy;
Her hart was pierst with pittie at the sight,
His feeble hart wide launched with loues cruell wound.
To whom her louing hart she linked fast
Nor saluage hart, but ruth of her sad plight
Yet had he not the hart, nor hardiment,
Fraile Ladies hart with loues consuming rage,
My hart doth melt with meere compassion,
That sure I weene, the hardest hart of stone,
Had so enranckled her malitious hart,
She weend, and wondrous gladnesse to her hart applyde.
The hart out of his brest: for sith her ded
Into his hart attonce: streight did he hayle
Both by the burning hart, which on his brest
But chiefly Paridell his hart did grate,
But to the wound his weake hart opened wyde;
Into his hart, which it did sorely gryde.
What stony hart, that heares thy haplesse fate,
And greedy eares her weake hart from her bore:
Both eyes and hart attonce, during the whyle
And all the sleights vnbosomd in his hart;
That she her loue and hart hath wholy sold
Consume his hart, and scorch his Idoles face,
And euer his faint hart much earned at the sight.
What Ladie, man? (said Trompart) take good hart,
That cheareful word his weake hart much did cheare,
That dreadfull sound the boasters hart did thrill,
But did his hart with bitter thoughts engore,
That all his hart with gealosie did swell;
That doth with curelesse care consume the hart,
To ioylesse dread, and mak'st the louing hart
Him grone, as if his hart were peeces made,
That pitty did the Virgins hart of patience rob.
And the sharpe steele doth riue her hart in tway,
And euer in your noble hart prepense,
Ah, how the fearefull Ladies tender hart
With which he pinched people to the hart,
At that wide orifice her trembling hart
Dreadfully dropping from her dying hart,
That horror gan the virgins hart to perse,
The cruell steele, which thrild her dying hart,
Thereat her noble hart was stonisht sore;
And as her tongue, so was her hart discided,
Approching nigh, eftsoones his wanton hart
His hart with secret enuie gan to swell,
Through hunger long, that hart to him doth lend,
The gentle Scudamour, whose hart whileare
The which like thornes did pricke his gealous hart,
He felt his hart for very paine to quake,
And pyning anguish hid in gentle hart,
For fell despight, and gnaw his gealous hart,
Ah cruell hand, and thrise more cruell hart,
And made ech member quake, and manly hart to quayle.
The which long time his grieued hart did wound,
Her hart did leape, and all her hart-strings tremble,
But Artegall close smyling ioy'd in secret hart.
Ne thinke th'affection of her hart to draw
But Scudamour whose hart twixt doubtfull feare
His hart was thrild with point of deadly feare;
Continuall siege vnto her gentle hart;
And thousand vowes from bottome of his hart
The louely Amoret, whose gentle hart
An hardy hart, and his wide mouth did gape
Streight into griefe, that her deare hart nigh swelt,
Her tender hart in peeces would diuide:
Which sory words her mightie hart did mate
Which passing through the eares, would pierce the hart,
His noble hart; thereto she did annexe
Into the lookers hart, and killeth farre away.
But she, whose hart to loue was wholly lent,
That her deare hart full deepely made to rew,
And doe dispart the hart with powre extreme,
Me seemes the gentle hart should most assured bind.
Nor hart could wish for any queint deuice,
That none might heare the sorrow of my hart,
Holding her hand vpon her gentle hart;
Whom soone as I beheld, my hart gan throb,
And wemens loue did from his hart expell,
But his hard rocky hart for no entreating
With that she wept and wail'd, as if her hart
The thought whereof empierst his hart so deepe,
That loue it was, which in his hart lay vnreuealed.
Ne lesse was she in secret hart affected,
That his great hart gan inwardly to swell
At sight thereof his cruell minded hart
No hand so cruell, nor no hart so hard,
That his bigge hart loth'd so vncomely vew.
Through stubborne handling of her loue-sicke hart;
Can dread of ought your dreadlesse hart withhold,
Euen at the markewhite of his hart she roued,
Conceiued close in her beguiled hart,
The more thereby her tender hart was payned.
His bodie was her thrall, his hart was freely plast.
Vnto the prison, where her hart did thrall remaine.
In her false hart, his bondage to vnbind;
Of his true hart so firmely was engraued,
Was ment to her, that neuer euill ment in hart.
She did prostrate, and with right humble hart,
Say on (quoth he) the secret of your hart:
First there came Pittie, with full tender hart,
With the neare touch whereof in tender hart
She gan take hart, and looke vp ioyfully:
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
Would haue embraced her with hart entyre.
Lookt vp with eyes full sad and hart full sore;
Wayting his foe, it did her dead hart cheare,
Her stubborne hart with inward deepe effect,
And both the eyes did steale the hart away.
Which when he saw, his hart was inly child
With which he wont to launch the saluage hart
Strooke him, as seemeth, vnderneath the hart,
Into his hart, and had so sternely wroke
An hart, not carried with too curious eyes,
And greatly ioy'd at his so noble hart,
His mightie hart their mournefull case can rew,
And from her sory hart few heauie words forth sigh't.
Which ye haue gathered to your gentle hart,
That euen his ruder hart began to rew,
Percing his hart with pities point did thrill;
And eke thy selfe, for want of manly hart,
Like as the gentle hart it selfe bewrayes,
Through such her stubborne stifnesse, and hard hart,
Her stubborne hart, which loue before disdayned,
For penaunce of my proud and hard rebellious hart.
And groning sore from grieued hart entire,
Whose sensefull words empierst his hart so neare,
Was readie oft his owne hart to deuoure,
His poysnous point deepe fixed in his hart
Who sighing sore, as if her hart in twaine
Had riuen bene, and all her hart strings brast,
That euen his hart for very fell despight,
His hart quite deaded was with anguish great,
But he, whose hart through feare was late fordonne,
His hart gan fayle, albe he saw them all asleepe.
Her gentle hart, that now long season past
Ne lesse in hart reioyced Calidore,
Then that of Amorets hart-binding chaine,
Who al this while lay bleeding out his hart-bloud neare.
With point of steele, that close his hartbloud spild,
Disloyall Treason, and hart-burning Hate,
That through long languour, and hart-burning brame
And to him said, Fie, fie, faint harted knight,
(Thereat full hartely laughed Satyrane.)
And found such fauour in their louing hartes,
In such disquiet and hartfretting payne,
Yet nathemore by his bold hartie speach,
With hartie words her knight she gan to cheare,
With stony eyes, and hartlesse hollow hew,
Then hopelesse hartlesse, gan the cunning thiefe
Nor fry in hartlesse griefe and dolefull teene.
The hartlesse Hind and Robucke to dismay,
Such when as hartlesse Trompart her did vew,
He seemed breathlesse, hartlesse, faint, and wan,
Thereto compelled through hart-murdring paine,
Till seeing them through suffrance hartned more,
Had felt the point of his hart-percing dart,
That had such might ouer true meaning harts;
But double griefs afflict concealing harts,
So been they parted both, with harts on edge,
Great ruth in all the gazers harts did grow,
Their harts she ghesseth by their humble guise,
Such ioy he had, their stubborne harts to quell,
And peoples harts with awfull terrour tye,
That suddeine horror to faint harts did show;
Th'eternall bale of heauie wounded harts;
Which when he knew, and felt ourfeeble harts
And harts of great Hero's doest enrage,
Or fell Erinnys, in your noble harts
Loue that two harts makes one, makes eke one will:
That word so deepe did in their harts impresse,
And with sweet science mollifide their stubborne harts.
And all mens harts in dew obedience held:
Some hauing heads like Harts, some like to Snakes,
Fraile harts, yet quenched not; like starry light
Could iudge what paines do louing harts perplexe.
Or rudely sdeigne a gentle harts request;
But as it falleth, in the gentlest harts
And choisest med'cine for sicke harts reliefe:
Her dearest sonne, her dearest harts delight.
Vile rancour their rude harts had fild with such despight.
Their wofull harts he wounded had whyleare,
How he their heedlesse harts with loue had fyred,
Ransackt the world, and in the wofull harts
With which he many weake harts had subdewed
On which their eies and harts were wholly set,
In th'harts of men, them gouerne wisely well,
Or to them tydings tell, that mote their harts delight.
For vertue is the band, that bindeth harts most sure.
Smart daunts not mighty harts, but makes them more to swell.
Harts grief, and bitter gall away to chace,
That able was weake harts away to steale.
And woxe nigh mad for very harts despight,
And setst thy kingdome in the captiue harts
From his false eyes, into their harts and parts entire.
Of louers lincked in true harts consent;
Whose luring baytes oftimes doe heedlesse harts entyse.
And their faint harts with senselesse horrour queld,
Giue her great comfort, and some harts content.
And sooth oft seene, that proudest harts base loue hath blynded.
Which when those knights had heard, their harts gan earne,
Of seruile yoke, that nobler harts repine.
In th'harts of many a knight, and many a gentle squire.
For loe the winged God, that woundeth harts,
Being his harts owne wish, and home with him did go.
And to insinuate his harts desire,
Whose hartstrings with keene steele nigh hewen be,
Of life him selfe, and hart-strings of an ï¿½ fï¿½EUR gle riued.
Her hart did leape, and all her hart-strings tremble,
And to him threatned his hart-thrilling speare:
To yield wide way to his hart-thrilling brond;
But with hart-thrilling throbs and bitter stowre,
To be hart-wounding loue, which should assay
Her harty words so deepe into the mynd
Whereof full glad for thirst, ech drunk an harty draught.
Who reapes the haruest sowen by his foe,
There is continuall spring, and haruest there
Should reap the haruest, ere it ripened were;
And Clare, and Harwitch both doth beautify:
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
The same so sore annoyed has the knight,
The noblest mind the best contentment has.
He that the wide West vnder his rule has,
The same she followes, till at last she has
Now when broad day the world discouered has,
She has forgot, how many a wofull stowre
Soone as the port from farre he has espide,
By him, who has the guerdon of his guile,
He has them now foure yeres besiegd to make the[m] thrall.
But all in vaine: for he has read his end
But he of rope or armes has now no memoree.
His dwelling has, low in an hollow caue,
The new Hierusalem, that God has built
That he his foe has hurt, and wounded sore,
And now he has pourd out his idle mind
For he has vowd, to beene aueng'd that day,
That in short space he has them qualifyde,
And now he has so long remained there,
For all so many weekes as the yeare has,
Ne yet has ended: for it was a great
Two dayes now in that sea he sayled has,
With his dull vapour all that desert has,
But the sage wisard telles, as he has red,
But who does wonder, that has red the Towre,
Led with eternall prouidence, that has
Old Genius, the which a double nature has.
That has no skill of Court nor courtesie,
Yet has full large to liue, and spend at libertie.
And also far vnlike conditions has;
That shortly she Malbecco has forgot,
Is woxen so deform'd, that he has quight
That he has gotten to a forrest neare,
The whiles the Championesse now entred has
Which, for my Muse her selfe now tyred has,
So ought each Knight, that vse of perill has,
That at the length he has yrent the dore,
So feeble skill of perfect things the vulgar has.
Of armes has knighthood stolne, yet Knight art none,
And broke their speares; yet neither has forgon
To proue her surname true, that she imposed has.
And now on earth it selfe enlarged has,
By a strong Tyrant, who inuaded has
Thereto a great aduauntage eke he has
It has the voice, that speaches forth doth send,
Till nigh vnto the place at length approcht he has.
So that he now has almost spent his spright.
Through feeblenesse, which all his limbes oppressed has.
Approcht in hast to greet his victorie,
In hast vnto his Lord, where he him left afore.
Thus well instructed, to their worke they hast,
In hast was climbing vp the Easterne hill,
Forthwith he runnes with feigned faithfull hast
How many mischieues should ensue his heedlesse hast.
And guiltie Elfin bloud shall sacrifice in hast.
In hast forsooke their rurall meriment,
The innocent pray in hast he does forsake,
And towards him they gan in hast to ride,
Therewith the knight thence marched forth in hast,
That hast with knightlesse guile and trecherous train
And catching vp in hast his three square shield,
Hath thee incenst, to hast thy dolefull fate?
In hast came rushing forth from inner bowre,
And said, Old sire, it seemes thou hast not red
O happy Queene of Faeries, that hast found
And fond, that ioyest in the woe thou hast,
Thou wretched man, of death hast greatest need,
Thou falsed hast thy faith with periurie,
With whom in all abuse thou hast thy selfe defilde?
In heauenly mercies hast thou not a part?
Hast wandred through the world now long a day;
But when thou famous victorie hast wonne,
And high emongst all knights hast hong thy shield,
That hast my name and nation red aright,
Halfe flying, and halfe footing in his hast,
And zealous hast away is quickly gone
Vnlucky Squire (said Guyon) sith thou hast
Henceforth take heede of that thou now hast past,
Then loe, where bound she sits, who[m]; thou hast sought,
Great glory and gay spoile sure hast thou got,
So hast thou oft with guile thine honour blent;
Then pittie, he in hast approched to the shore.
And hast he rose, for to remoue aside
That here in desert hast thine habitaunce,
Or where hast thou thy wonne, that so much gold
But sith thou hast found fauour in mine eye,
False traitour miscreant, thou broken hast
Right sowre, & feele the law, the which thou hast defast.
Traytour what hast thou doen? how euer may
And now faire Phoebus gan decline in hast
That ouer mortall minds hast so great might,
Whom long he lou'd, for him in hast did send,
Hast learn'd to loue, let no whit thee dismay
I read thee soone retyre, whiles thou hast might,
And made more hast, the life to haue bereau'd:
Into the woods thenceforth in hast she went,
That thou hast shewed to me sinfull wight,
That hast from darkenesse me returnd to light,
Hast drest my sinfull wounds? I kisse thy blessed feete.
Nor wearinesse to slacke her hast, but fled
Went forth in hast, and did her footing trace
Which whenas Satyrane beheld, in hast
Which thou vpon thy selfe hast lately ta'ne?
Great labour fondly hast thou hent in hand,
That hast a thanklesse seruice on thee ta'ne,
Your zealous hast, till morrow next againe
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
His wicked bookes in hast he ouerthrew,
False faitour Scudamour, that hast by slight
So hast thou to thy selfe false honour often wonne.
Vnworthy life that loue with guile hast gotten,
That hast with shamefull spot of sinfull lust
Now stood, came forth in hast to take his part,
For hast did ouer-runne, in dust enrould,
In hast she from her lofty chaire descended,
That neither could in hast themselues againe vpreare.
And squiers make hast to helpe their Lords fordonne.
What glorie, or what guerdon hast thou found
Hast thou in all this time, from him vnknowne
Ran forth in hast with hideous outcry,
And makes her feare a spur to hast her flight:
Doth hast to crosse him by the nearest way,
She ran in hast his life to haue bereft:
Therewith she rose in hast, and her addrest
Therefore to Tryphon she againe doth hast,
Whom he requir'd his forward hast to stay,
He saw no way, but close with him in hast;
That hast with borrowed plumes thy selfe endewed,
When thou hast all this doen, then bring me newes
With gladfull hast, in hope of him to get
She to them runnes in hast, and her haire rends,
Nathelesse him selfe he armed all in hast,
She towards him in hast her selfe did draw,
The which hast me, of all most wretched wight,
But scorne of armes that hast with guilty hand
With that a Dwarfe she cald to her in hast,
The Dwarfe his way did hast, and went all night;
As by thy worth thou worthily hast wonne,
But as thou hast thy steed forlorne with shame,
Came forth in hast: where when as with the dead
Hast slaine my men in this vnmanly maner,
And eke all knights hast shamed with this knightlesse part.
Yet further hast thou heaped shame to shame,
Himselfe in hast he arm'd, and did him fast pursew.
To finish then, for other present hast.
That warn'd the shepheards to their homes to hast
Which Coridon first hearing, ran in hast
Therefore resoluing to returne in hast
So full of ioy, streight forth she ran in hast
But forth in hast ran to the straunger Mayd;
Therewith in haste his helmet gan vnlace,
In haste Duessa from her place arose,
To come vnto his wished home in haste,
O foolish men, why haste ye to your owne decay?
Her golden lockes for haste were loosely shed
Whereto he drew in haste it to agree.
But Guyon after him in haste did hie,
That bad him come in haste. He by and by
When as their Captaine heard, in haste he yode,
And sent in haste for Tryphon, to apply
Doubleth her haste for feare to be for-hent,
With no lesse haste, and eke with no lesse dreed,
O Titan, haste to reare thy ioyous waine:
Embreaded were for hindring of her haste,
His charet swift in haste he thither steard,
The whiles her husband ranne with sory haste,
With such amazement, that in haste he fled,
Vnto the shinie heauen in haste she hide,
That after him he ran with zealous haste,
Therefore descending backe in haste, he sought
That if ye list to haste a litle more,
Whence neither greatly hasted to arise,
But turn'd abacke, and to retyre him hasted
Good cause he had to hasten thence away;
Thus fowle to hasten your vntimely date;
His flaming head did hasten for to steepe,
To hasten greatly to his parties ayd,
One pricking towards them with hastie heat,
His hastie hand he doth amazed hold,
His haire, and hastie tongue, that did offend:
Yet sad he was that his too hastie speed
Late learnd what harme to hastie trust ensu'th,
Him to his castle brought with hastie forse,
Her hastie ruine does more heauie make,
With which sad instrument of hastie death,
She would commaund the hastie Sunne to stay,
Vprose with hastie ioy, and feeble speed
And wondred at his breathlesse hastie mood.
Whose hastie hand so farre from reason strayd,
And suffred not in wrath his hastie steps to stray.
Him hastie to arise. As one affright
Appease his heat, or hastie passage stay;
The hastie heat of his auowd reuenge delayd.
But bent his hastie course towards the idle flood.
With hastie gallop towards her did ryde;
But nothing might relent her hastie flight;
And euer hastie Night he blamed bitterlie.
At length when as he saw her hastie heat
Vnto the ward, to open to him hastilie.
To Morpheus house doth hastily repaire.
Then vp he rose, and clad him hastily;
Who after her as hastily gan scowre,
And left the doubtfull battell hastily,
Vnto his aide she hastily did draw
A varlet running towards hastily,
That nothing should him hastily awake:
Come hither, come hither, Ã´ come hastily;
Binding her sister, she to him ran hastily.
As faire Aurora rising hastily,
Tho hastily remounting to his steed,
Till Trompart ronning hastily, him did stay,
